newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay index soars 1.6 pct, shrs end at day's best.
newsitem.headline: Bombay index soars 1.6 pct, shrs end at day's best.

text.p: ** (1005 GMT) - Bombay stocks finish near day's highest
levels, index jumps 66.91 points, or 1.60 percent, at
4,253.20 provisional close, just shy of day's highs
** National Exchange index ends 28.25 pts, 2.41 pct higher,
at 1,201.50 provisional close at start of new
account trade
** Blue chips in third day of consecutive rally boosted by
strong foreign fund buying
** Multinational, software stocks lead charge in day's
rally -- traders
** Expectations that market regulator might approve
modified carry-forward trade buoy market sentiments
** Monsoon session of India's parliament starts off noisily
with both upper and lower houses adjourned over
lawmakers' demands for dimissal of two regional govts
Bombay stocks powered to a strong close on Wednesday, extending the market's two-day old winning streak with shares of multinational companies topping the day's action, traders said.

"Some kind of bullishness is partly due to expectations by the investing community that the revised carry-forward report will be accepted by the Securities & Exchange Board of India (SEBI)," Alok Sethi, director at Natwest Markets, told Reuters. A SEBI-appointed panel on Tuesday submitted recommendations for an easier carry-forward trading system.
"Also, the markets had dipped reasonably and (last week) and so we are kind of recovering," Natwest's Sethi said.
Political worries forced the Bombay index to post its biggest week-to-week fall, down five percent last week. The Bombay index has since recouped three percent of the losses.
Hectic bidding was noticed in fast-moving consumer goods stocks (FMCG) by foreign funds and local funds, traders said.
They said newspaper reports that the U.S.'s Alliance Capital planned to float a $60-million offshore fund targeting Indian FMCG stocks led to renewed action in these shares.
"We are talking to people. If there is interest in the fund, we might take a decision next month," an official at Alliance Capital told Reuters.
Shares of Colgate rose 12.0 rupees to 317.25, Nestle gained 6.75 rupees at 293.50, Hindustan Lever added 26.20 at 1,362.0 and Ponds jumped 71.75 to 1,805.0.
